choices.text: Oral glucose challenge test with GH level
Insulin like growth factor 1 binding potein -3 (IGFBP-3 )
Insulin like growth factor -1 levels
Random growth hormone levels

questions.text: A 44 yr old man is referred to your center for management of severe hyperglycemia. During examination, you note that patient has enlarged feet, coarse facial features, and prognathism. You suspect acromegaly. Which of the following tests can you use as a screening method for this condition ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin like growth factor-1 levels

 

Acromegaly is a clinical syndrome that results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH). Produced mainly in the pituitary gland, GH controls the physical growth of the body. In adults, too much of this hormone causes bones, cartilage, body organs, and other tissues to increase in size. Acromegaly is most often diagnosed in middle-aged adults, but symptoms can appear at any age. In children, too much growth hormone causes a condition called gigantism rather than acromegaly.

 

Best screening test for acromegaly is serum insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral glucose challenge test with GH level: While this test is used to diagnose acromegaly by demonstrating a lack of GH suppression after glucose administration, it is more complex and typically performed after IGF-1 screening suggests acromegaly.

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factor 1 binding protein-3 (IGFBP-3): Although IGFBP-3 levels are influenced by GH, they are not routinely used for screening acromegaly.

 

Option D. Random growth hormone levels: These levels can fluctuate significantly throughout the day and are influenced by various factors, making random GH levels unreliable for diagnosing acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum IGF-1 is the preferred initial test for screening acromegaly due to its reliability and the persistence of elevated levels in the presence of excessive GH production. This test provides a stable indicator of disease activity and is less variable than direct GH measurements.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is found to be positive for HBsAg and HBeAg and is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B. The viral load of the patient was 2 x 10^5 IU/mL and ALT is found to be doubled. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tenofovir

 

The patient is diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B, as indicated by the positive HBsAg and HBeAg, which are markers of infection and infectivity, respectively. The viral load of 2 x 105 IU/mL and elevated ALT levels suggest active viral replication and liver inflammation.

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): This is a marker of infection. Its presence indicates that the person is infectious.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): This is a marker of infectivity. It indicates that the virus is replicating and the patient is highly infectious.

 

HBV DNA: This is a marker of viral replication. In chronic hepatitis B, a high level of HBV DNA correlates with an increased risk of complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

The decision to start treatment in chronic hepatitis B is primarily based on the levels of HBV DNA and ALT. According to guidelines, treatment is indicated if:

 

  1. HBV DNA is more than 2000 IU/mL.
  2. ALT is elevated (more than 2 to 3 times the upper limit of normal).

 

In this patient, both criteria are met.

 

Tenofovir is preferred for its efficacy and lower risk of resistance compared to other options like lamivudine. Tenofovir is also favored over interferon-based therapies due to better durability of response and lower side effect profile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamivudine: This drug is no longer preferred due to a high risk of resistance.

 

Option C. Peg IFN for 52 weeks: Pegylated interferon is not preferred due to less favorable response rates and a higher side effect profile compared to tenofovir.

 

Option D. Combined peg IFN with lamivudine: Combination therapy with pegylated interferon and lamivudine is not recommended due to increased side effects and no significant improvement in efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tenofovir is the preferred treatment for chronic hepatitis B with high viral load and elevated ALT levels due to its efficacy and lower risk of resistance.

questions.text: FISH is used to detect all of the following except? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Point mutation

 

FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is a cytogenetic technique that allows for the detection of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It is particularly useful in identifying chromosomal abnormalities such as translocations, amplifications, deletions, and aneuploidies (such as trisomy or monosomy). These alterations are detectable because they involve large-scale changes in the chromosomal structure or number that can be visualized using fluorescent probes.

 

However, FISH is not suitable for detecting point mutations. Point mutations are changes at the single nucleotide level, which are too small to be detected by this method. Point mutations require techniques that can analyze DNA sequences at a higher resolution, such as PCR-based methods, sequencing, or allele-specific oligonucleotide hybridization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translocation: FISH can detect translocations, which involve the rearrangement of chromosome segments between nonhomologous chromosomes. This can be visualized by the hybridization pattern of fluorescent probes.

 

Option B. Amplification: FISH is effective in detecting gene amplification, where multiple copies of a particular region of the chromosome are present, resulting in an intense signal from the corresponding fluorescent probe.

 

Option C. Deletion: FISH can identify deletions, including microdeletions, by showing the absence of a fluorescent signal where the DNA sequence is missing from the chromosome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH is a cytogenetic technique used to detect chromosomal-level changes such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions but is not capable of detecting point mutations at the nucleotide level

choices.text: Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
Reduced cardiac contractility
Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation

 

Nitrates cause endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation when treating Prinzmetal angina.

 

Coronary artery vasospasm is the underlying cause of Prinzmetal angina. By relaxing the smooth muscles of the epicardial coronary arteries, nitrates treat coronary artery spasm.

 

The main mechanism of action of nitrates in the event of stable angina is preferred vein dilation (by increasing cGMP). Venous return to the heart is reduced as a result of venous dilatation (preload). Due to the reduction in ventricular end-diastolic volume, myocardial oxygen consumption also reduces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced cardiac contractility: This is not the primary mechanism of action of nitrates in relieving Prinzmetal angina. Nitrates primarily work by vasodilation rather than affecting myocardial contractility.

 

Option C. Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume: Nitrates generally reduce the preload (venous return) by dilating veins, which can lead to a decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume, not an increase.

 

Option D. Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure: While nitrates can lower blood pressure, the primary therapeutic effect in Prinzmetal angina is not related to diastolic perfusion pressure but to the direct vasodilation of the coronary arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitrates provide symptomatic relief in Prinzmetal angina through endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation, which helps to alleviate coronary artery spasms and restore proper blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She is worried about her conception chances. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bromocriptine

 

Explanation:

 

The choice of dopamine agonist therapy for hyperprolactinemia in patients desiring fertility remains somewhat controversial. Advanced textbooks such as "Speroff's Clinical Gynecologic Endocrinology and Infertility" clearly highlight that cabergoline has greater potency, fewer side effects, better tolerability, and convenient dosing compared to bromocriptine, leading to its general preference for prolactinoma treatment.

 

However, Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine (21st Edition) explicitly mentions:

 

“Because cabergoline is long-acting with a high D₂-receptor affinity, it is not recommended for use in women when fertility is desired.”

 

Considering the context of Indian postgraduate entrance examinations, it is advisable to adhere to Harrison's recommendations. Therefore, although cabergoline is generally considered superior, bromocriptine is the safer and recommended answer for this specific examination scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cabergoline: Although generally preferred for routine prolactinoma management, it is explicitly not recommended during conception planning as per Harrison’s.

 

Option C. Octreotide: A somatostatin analog indicated exclusively for GH-secreting tumors, not prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: A GH receptor antagonist used specifically in acromegaly, with no role in prolactinoma or fertility management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For Indian PG entrance examinations, bromocriptine remains the recommended first-line treatment in women with microprolactinoma who desire fertility, despite cabergoline’s clinical advantages, based on guidelines explicitly mentioned in Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine.

questions.text: Which of the following infections presents with a rash that characteristically spreads from the extremities towards the center of the body? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Epidemic typhus

 

Explanation:

 

Epidemic typhus is characterized by a rash that starts on the upper trunk, usually on the fifth day, and then becomes generalized, involving the entire body except the face, palms, and soles. This rash begins peripherally and moves centrally, which is the hallmark of a non-centrally distributed rash.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Measles: The rash of measles begins as erythematous macules behind the ears and on the neck and hairline. The rash progresses to involve the face, trunk, and arms, with involvement of the legs and feet by the end of the second day. This distribution does not describe a non-centrally distributed rash.

 

Option C. Secondary syphilis: The skin rash of secondary syphilis typically involves the entire body, including the palms and soles. This rash is not specifically non-centrally distributed.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid fever presents with rose spots primarily on the trunk and chest. The distribution of these rose spots does not align with a non-centrally distributed rash.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Epidemic typhus is distinguished by a rash that starts peripherally and moves centrally, making it a non-centrally distributed rash.

questions.text:
Under which circumstances is live vaccination not contraindicated? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. DiGeorge syndrome
  2. Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome
  3. Ataxia telangiectasia
  4. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4 only

 

Live vaccinations are generally contraindicated in individuals with certain immunodeficiency disorders because their immune systems may not be able to handle the attenuated (weakened) pathogens in the vaccines, potentially leading to severe infections. However, there are exceptions based on the nature of the immunodeficiency.

 

  • Complement deficiency: This is a condition where components of the complement system (a part of the immune system) are deficient. Complement deficiencies do not affect the cellular immune response significantly, meaning that the risk of adverse effects from live vaccinations is not increased. Therefore, individuals with complement deficiency can receive live vaccines safely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome involves a defect in T-cell production due to thymic hypoplasia. Since T-cells are crucial for mounting an immune response to vaccines, live vaccines are contraindicated.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: This is a condition characterized by defects in both the immune system and DNA repair mechanisms. Patients with this condition have a higher risk of developing severe infections from live vaccines, so they are contraindicated.

 

Option D. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder affecting both the immune system and platelet production. Individuals with Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome are at risk for severe infections from live vaccines due to their compromised immune function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Complement deficiency does not pose a contraindication for live vaccination.

 

However, it is important to note that live vaccines should be avoided in individuals with DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia telangiectasia, because these are immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a history of fall 1 year back with parietal bone fracture, has now presented with a painful and growing parietal swelling. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growing fracture

 

The likely diagnosis is a growing fracture, also known as a traumatic leptomeningeal cyst or encephalocele. This condition occurs when a skull fracture, particularly one associated with a dural tear, fails to heal properly. The enlargement of the fracture site may be due to the herniation of brain tissue, dilated ventricles, or the formation of a leptomeningeal cyst.

 

Clinical features of a growing fracture:

 

  • It typically occurs in children younger than 3 years old.
  • The condition is usually detected within a year of the initial head injury.
  • It presents as a localized swelling or palpable skull defect that tends to increase in size.
  • If not detected early, it can present later with symptoms such as headaches, seizures, or neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Growing scalp hematoma: This condition would typically be associated with a history of jaundice and falling hemoglobin levels, which are not described in this case.

 

Option C. Subdural hygroma: Common presentations include fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, and confusion. These symptoms are not consistent with the presentation described in this question.

 

Option D. Chronic abscess: A chronic abscess usually presents with a long history of fever and signs of sepsis, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


A growing fracture is a rare but serious condition in young children, often presenting as a growing swelling over a skull fracture site within a year of the initial injury. Early detection and treatment are crucial to prevent long-term complications.

choices.text: Addison's disease

questions.text: These findings are suggestive of which of the following conditions
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acromegaly

 

Explanation:  

 

The images provided show a patient with coarse facial features, prognathism (protruding jaw), frontal bossing (prominent forehead), and prominent jaw bones. These are characteristic features of acromegaly, a condition caused by excessive growth hormone (GH) production, usually due to a pituitary adenoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Addison's disease: Characterized by hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and weight loss, not by coarse facial features.

 

Option B. Gigantism: Also caused by excess GH, but it occurs before the closure of the growth plates in children and adolescents, leading to increased height and growth of long bones. The facial features are not as prominent as in acromegaly.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Characterized by features such as central obesity, moon face, buffalo hump, and purple striae, not by coarse facial features and prognathism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acromegaly is diagnosed based on characteristic facial features such as coarse facial features, prognathism, and frontal bossing, resulting from excessive growth hormone production.

questions.text: The enzyme that is common for both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phosphoglycerate kinase

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase catalyzes the conversion of 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to 3-phosphoglycerate, which is a reversible step involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis hence it is common for both pathways.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is involved only in glycolysis and catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not involved in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option B. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is a key regulatory enzyme in glycolysis, converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate. It does not play a role in gluconeogenesis.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase is involved in gluconeogenesis, converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate. It is not involved in glycolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphoglycerate kinase is a common enzyme in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, catalyzing a reversible reaction that interconverts 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate and 3-phosphoglycerate.

 

Other reversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Phosphoglycerate mutase
  • Glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase
  • Triose phosphate isomerase
  • Aldolase
  • Phosphohexose isomerase

questions.text: All among the following are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a serious gastrointestinal problem that mostly affects premature infants. It involves infection and inflammation that causes destruction of the bowel (intestine) or part of the bowel.

 

This is not a typical feature of NEC. Instead, NEC can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis due to the severe infection and inflammation affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

The typical clinical features of NEC include:

 

Option A. Vomiting: Vomiting is a common symptom in infants with NEC due to gastrointestinal dysfunction.

 

Option B. Abdominal mass: In severe cases, an abdominal mass can be palpated due to distended bowel loops filled with gas or fluid.

 

Option C. Erythema of the abdominal wall: This is seen in advanced stages of NEC, indicating severe inflammation and possible progression to perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arm span

 

The image shows the measurement of a child's height using a stadiometer. The alternative method that can be used for measuring height is arm span. The arm span is a measurement from the tip of one middle finger to the tip of the other middle finger when the arms are outstretched horizontally. This measurement is typically close to the child's height and can be used as an alternative method, especially in cases where the child is unable to stand properly.

 

The proportion of arm span to height changes with age but is generally close to the height measurement. In clinical practice, when direct measurement of height is not feasible, arm span can be a reliable surrogate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head circumference: Head circumference is measured using a measuring tape and is an important metric in assessing brain growth and development, especially in infants and young children, but it is not an alternative for height measurement.

 

Option C. Crown-rump length: Crown-rump length is a measurement used during an ultrasound in early pregnancy to estimate the gestational age of the fetus, not a method for height measurement in children.

 

Option D. Knee height: Knee height is not typically used for measuring height in children and is more often used in adults, particularly the elderly, to estimate height when they are unable to stand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arm span can be used as an alternative method for measuring height, especially when direct height measurement is not feasible.

choices.text: Hollow viscus perforation
Small bowel obstruction

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of worsening abdominal pain and obstipation. He reports sustaining a blunt abdominal injury three days ago. On examination, he has a tense and tender abdomen with signs of guarding. The provided chest X-ray in the erect position shows an abnormal finding. Based on his history, clinical presentation, and imaging, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray image shows free air under the diaphragm, a classic radiographic sign of a hollow viscus perforation, most commonly caused by trauma, peptic ulcer disease, or bowel injury. In this case, the patient's history of blunt abdominal trauma, worsening pain, and obstipation strongly support the diagnosis.

 

Key Points

 

Radiographic Findings:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm in an erect chest X-ray is a typical finding indicative of a perforated hollow viscus.

 

Clinical Presentation:

 

Patients with hollow viscus perforation often present with severe abdominal pain, obstipation, and signs of peritonitis, including tenderness, guarding, and signs of acute abdomen.

 

The pain is usually worsened by movement, and systemic signs such as tachycardia, nausea, vomiting, and fever may also be present.

 

Septic shock may develop in severe cases due to peritoneal contamination.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

Perforation of a hollow organ, such as the intestines or stomach, leads to leakage of air and contents into the peritoneal cavity, causing acute bacterial peritonitis. This inflammation can be localized or generalized and requires urgent management.

 

Management:

 

The management of hollow viscus perforation involves surgical intervention, typically laparotomy, to repair the perforation and treat peritonitis.

 

Supportive care includes pain management, fluid resuscitation, and antibiotics to control infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Acute pancreatitis: Typically presents with epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and no free air under the diaphragm on imaging.

 

Option C) Small bowel obstruction: Presents with abdominal distension, vomiting, and no free air under the diaphragm; air-fluid levels are more common.

 

Option D) Traumatic splenic rupture: Would present with left upper quadrant pain, signs of hemorrhagic shock, and free fluid rather than free air on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hollow viscus perforation is a critical diagnosis characterized by abdominal pain, peritonitis, and the presence of free air under the diaphragm on imaging. Prompt surgical intervention is essential to prevent severe complications such as sepsis and death.

questions.text: Diabetic drug that should be stopped immediately with a creatinine of 5.6mg/dl? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metformin

 

Metformin, a commonly prescribed medication for type 2 diabetes, primarily works by reducing hepatic glucose production. It is contraindicated in patients with significant renal impairment due to the risk of lactic acidosis, a potentially life-threatening condition.

 

It is to be stopped if creatinine level >1.5mg/dl in men and >1.4mg/dl in women

 

MOA of metformin- reduces hepatic glucose production.

 

Adverse effects - nausea, diarrhea, lactic acidosis, vit b12 deficiency

 

Contraindications:  serum creatinine 1.5 (in males)/ 1.4(females)

 

GFR<30ml/min, Unstable CHF, Hepatic failure, Acidosis, Hospitalized patients who cannot take anything orally

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Linagliptin: This is a DPP-4 inhibitor, which does not require adjustment for kidney disease and is not directly harmful in renal failure.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for cardiovascular conditions including hypertension; not directly affected by renal function in terms of drug safety, though dosing may need adjustment.

 

Option D. Insulin: Often required in higher doses or with careful monitoring in renal impairment due to decreased insulin clearance, but not contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metformin should be discontinued in patients with a creatinine level above 1.5 mg/dL for men and 1.4 mg/dL for women, or a GFR below 30 mL/min to avoid the risk of lactic acidosis, especially in the context of significant renal impairment.

questions.text: The graph below shows oxygen dissociation curves. What does the curve marked as red indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

The curve 'A' shows a hyperbolic curve that is characteristic of oxygen dissociation in myoglobin.

 

 

The red curve in the graph indicates the oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin. This curve is hyperbolic, which is characteristic of myoglobin's oxygen binding properties.

 

Myoglobin: Myoglobin can bind only one oxygen molecule and does not exhibit cooperative binding like hemoglobin. This results in a hyperbolic oxygen dissociation curve, which means myoglobin has a very high affinity for oxygen and releases it only at low partial pressures of oxygen (PO2). This high affinity allows myoglobin to effectively store oxygen in muscle tissues and release it during periods of low oxygen availability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carboxyhemoglobin: The dissociation curve for carboxyhemoglobin would show a leftward shift and a reduced maximal oxygen carrying capacity due to carbon monoxide binding with high affinity to hemoglobin, but it would not have the hyperbolic shape seen with myoglobin.

 

Option C. Methemoglobin: Methemoglobin has an oxidized form of iron that cannot bind oxygen effectively. The curve would show a decreased oxygen carrying capacity but would not match the hyperbolic shape of the myoglobin curve.

 

Option D. Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF): Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen compared to adult hemoglobin, resulting in a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. However, it still exhibits cooperative binding, unlike myoglobin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, indicating its high affinity for oxygen and its role in oxygen storage within muscle tissues. This curve differs from the sigmoidal curve of hemoglobin, which exhibits cooperative binding.

questions.text: Night blindness history, corneal drying and patient has Bitot’s spots. Which of the following is found in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phrynoderma

 

The symptoms of patient clearly indicate vitamin A deficiency. One of the other clinical feature of vitamin A deficiency is follicular hyperkeratosis aka Phrynoderma which is characterized by excessive keratinization of certain area of body such as elbows and knees. Vitamin A prevents hyperkeratinization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratosis pilaris rubra: Keratosis pilaris rubra is a skin condition characterized by the appearance of small, red bumps on the skin, often on the arms and thighs. It primarily affects the skin and does not directly relate to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Eczema: Eczema is a chronic skin condition characterized by red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches. While eczema can affect the skin, it is not associated with night blindness, corneal drying, or Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis: Ichthyosis is a group of genetic skin disorders that lead to dry, scaly, and thickened skin. It primarily affects the skin's texture and is not commonly associated with night blindness and corneal drying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of night blindness, corneal drying, and Bitot's spots, are indications of vitamin A deficiency. Phrynoderma, which is characterized by goosebump-like skin changes, is a manifestation of severe vitamin A deficiency and is the most relevant option in this context.

 

Ref-Dinesh Puri 3rd e/pg. 393,

choices.text: Epithelial cell tumor
Germ cell tumor
Sex cord stromal tumor
Granulosa cell tumor

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cell tumor

 

Explanation:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified under epithelial cell tumors. Epithelial ovarian tumors originate from the cells that line the surface of the ovary. Clear cell carcinoma is a subtype of epithelial ovarian tumors.

 

Classification of ovarian tumors:

 

  1. Epithelial Cell Tumor
    • Serous
    • Mucinous
    • Brenner
    • Clear cell
    • Endometrioid
    • Clear cell carcinoma falls under this category.
  2. Germ Cell Tumor
    • Dysgerminoma
    • Yolk sac tumor
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma
    • Embryonal
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not classified here.
  3. Sex Cord Stromal Tumor
    • Granulosa cell tumor
    • Thecoma
    • Fibroma
    • Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor
    • Clear cell carcinoma is not included in this category.

 

Educational Objective:


Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified as an epithelial cell tumor.

 

Ref: Page no 291, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains
﻿﻿﻿The compound has one ionisable group

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

 

The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B, which corresponds to the pk1, and pk2 of the compound.

 

The above graph resembles the titration curve of the amino acid glycine.

 

Titration curve of Glycine:

 

 

The titration is completed at a pH of 12, where the glycine predominantly exists in the form of H2N - CH2 - COO.

 

pK1, and pK2, correspond to the point where the buffering capacity is maximum.

 

Characteristics of the titration curve:

  • ﻿﻿Buffering capacity is referred to as the ability of the amino acid to resist the change in pH due to the addition of acid (H+) or base (OH- equivalents), by accepting or losing the protons respectively.
  • ﻿﻿An ionizable group refers to the group which can either lose or accept a proton and becomes negatively charged or positively charged ion respectively.
  • ﻿﻿During the titration, the buffering capacity of the compound reaches its maximum, at points where the pKa of the ionizable groups is reached.
  • ﻿﻿Each of these pKa are labeled as pK1, pK2, pK3, etc.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of two pKs indicates that the compound has two ionizable groups. Ex. Glycine.
  • ﻿﻿The presence of three or more pKs indicates the presence of side chains on the amino acid, with additional ionizable groups.
  • ﻿﻿Ex. histidine has three ionizable groups, an amino group, an imidazole group (on the side chain), and a carboxyl group. The pKas of these groups respectively correspond to the pK1, pK2, pK3 of the titration curve of histidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group: Points A and B represent the pKa values, not the range of maximum ionization. The range of maximum ionization would be broader than just the pKa points.

 

Option C. The compound has three ionisable side chains: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups. A compound with three ionizable groups would have three pKa values.

 

Option D. The compound has one ionisable group: The graph shows two pKa values, indicating two ionizable groups (an amino group and a carboxyl group).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The points A and B on the titration curve represent the maximum buffering capacity of the compound, corresponding to the pKa values of the ionizable groups. The graph shown likely represents an amino acid like glycine, which has two ionizable groups.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with muscle weakness, fatigue, and persistent hypertension. Laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause of her symptoms. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension?
questions.solution:
Answer: B)  Liddle syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Primary hyperaldosteronism is characterized by excessive aldosterone production, which leads to increased sodium reabsorption, potassium excretion, and hydrogen ion loss. This results in hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Conditions causing similar presentations include Liddle syndrome, apparent mineralocorticoid excess, and glucocorticoid remediable hyperaldosteronism, all of which involve aldosterone or mineralocorticoid receptor activation pathways.

 

Common Causes of Hypokalemia + Hypertension:

 

Liddle syndrome: ENaC channel gain-of-function mutation.

 

Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess: Due to 11β-HSD loss of function, leading to increased cortisol stimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors.

 

Geller syndrome and GRA: Conditions involving abnormal aldosterone regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Bartter syndrome: Characterized by hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but with normotension.

 

Option C) Gitelman syndrome: Presents with hypokalemia and alkalosis but also normotension.

 

Option D) Gordon syndrome: Associated with hypertension and hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension is typically associated with conditions involving excessive aldosterone or mineralocorticoid receptor activity, such as primary hyperaldosteronism. Differentiating these conditions from syndromes that present with normotension or hyperkalemia is essential for appropriate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moist heat

 

  • In the case scenario given above the patient has suffered from a ‘Scald injury’

  • Clinical presentation - erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation

  • Cause of scald - application of liquid above 60°C or from steam which is moist heat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electric burn: Electric burns typically have entry and exit points and are caused by electrical currents passing through the body, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Chemical burn: Chemical burns result from exposure to corrosive substances and may have different patterns and additional signs such as discoloration or tissue damage beyond just blisters and erythema.

 

Option C. Dry heat: Burns caused by dry heat, such as flames or hot objects, usually present with charring or a different burn pattern compared to scald injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.

 

TYPES of SCALD INJURIES

 

  • Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.

  • Accidental Splash burns

  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV MgSO4

 

The ECG displays characteristics consistent with Torsades de Pointes (Tdp), which is identified by its distinctive polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and a prolonged QT interval. In the setting of pre-eclampsia, magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is not only used for seizure prophylaxis but also effectively treats Torsades de Pointes by stabilizing the cardiac membrane and correcting magnesium deficiency, a common trigger for this arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV calcium: Used for treating hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia-induced cardiac toxicity, not directly effective for Torsades de Pointes.

 

Option B. DC Shock: Indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with Tdp or other life-threatening arrhythmias, which does not apply here as the patient's vitals are stable.

 

Option D. Synchronized cardioversion: Typically used for managing ventricular tachycardia with a pulse or superventricular tachycardia, but not the first-line for Torsades de Pointes in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable pregnant patient displaying Torsades de Pointes, especially in the context of pre-eclampsia, IV magnesium sulfate is the recommended treatment. It helps in both controlling the arrhythmia and providing prophylaxis against eclamptic seizures.

questions.text: Identify the cells marked in the given image? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphocyte- 1, Monocyte-4, Eosinophil-2, Basophil-3, Neutrophil -5

 

 

A peripheral blood smear shows RBCs, WBCs (granulocytes and agranulocytes), and platelets.

 

1. Lymphocyte : Lymphocytes are slightly larger than red blood cells (RBCs) and have a large, dense nucleus with little cytoplasm and no granules.

 

4. Monocyte : Monocytes are the largest WBCs with a kidney-shaped nucleus and abundant cytoplasm without granules.

 

2. Eosinophil : Eosinophils have bilobed nuclei (spectacle-shaped) with large, brick-red (eosinophilic) granules in the cytoplasm.

 

3. Basophil : Basophils have large bluish granules that obscure the nucleus, which is often difficult to see due to the dense granulation.

 

5. Neutrophil : Neutrophils typically have a multi-lobed (3-5 lobes) nucleus and fine bluish granules in the cytoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulocytes:

 

  • Neutrophil - 3 to 5 lobed nucleus with small, bluish granules in the cytoplasm
  • Eosinophil - Binucleate/spectacle shaped nuclei with brick-red granules in the cytoplasm
  • Basophil- Large bluish granules in the cytoplasm which obscure the nucleus.

 

Agranulocytes:

 

  • Lymphocytes- size just larger than an BC. No granules, no nucleoli present.
  • Monocytes - largest cells with a kidney-shaped nucleus.

questions.text: In which of the following reflexes, gastric emptying is delayed when acidic content enters the duodenum?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Enterogastric

 

Explanation

 

Enterogastric reflex is the reflex that inhibits gastric emptying. It is elicited by the presence of chyme in the duodenum, which prevents further emptying of stomach.

 

Mechanism of enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Presence of chyme in duodenum causes generation of nerve impulses which are transmitted to stomach by the intrinsic nerve fibers of GI tract. After reaching the stomach, these impulses inhibit emptying.
  2. Impulses from duodenum pass via extrinsic sympathetic fibers to stomach and inhibit emptying.
  3. Some impulses from duodenum travel through afferent vagal fibers to the brainstem. Normally, brainstem neurons send excitatory impulses to stomach through efferent vagal fibers and stimulate gastric emptying. However, the impulses from duodenum inhibit these brainstem neurons and thereby inhibit gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrocolic Reflex: Incorrect. The gastrocolic reflex triggers increased colonic motility in response to food entering the stomach. It does not directly affect gastric emptying.

 

Option B. Enterocolic Reflex: Incorrect. This is not a widely recognized reflex within standard physiological texts; it does not pertain specifically to the control of gastric emptying.

 

Option C. Gastroileal Reflex: Incorrect. The gastroileal reflex stimulates the movement of chyme from the ileum into the large intestine following food intake, which is unrelated to the initial inhibition of gastric emptying.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterogastric reflex plays a critical role in regulating the rate at which the stomach empties its contents into the duodenum, particularly under conditions where the chyme is highly acidic. This regulation ensures that the duodenum can adequately process the chyme without being overwhelmed, which is crucial for maintaining digestive health and preventing duodenal irritation or damage.

 

Factors which initiate enterogastric reflex

 

  1. Duodenal distension
  2. Irritation of the duodenal mucosa
  3. Acidity of the chyme
  4. Osmolality of the chyme
  5. Breakdown products of proteins and fats

questions.text: Best method of diagnosis for Clostridium difficile? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Toxin gene detection by PCR

 

Nucleic acid amplification tests, including PC assays, for C. difficile toxin A or B gene in stool have been approved for diagnostic purposes of Clostridium difficile infection due to high sensitivity, specificity and rapid turnaround time.

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

 

  1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
  2. Toxin A or B detected in the stool, toxin- producing C. difficile detected in the stool by PCR or ELISA, or pseudo membranes seen in the colon.

 

Other diagnostic methods include:

 

  • Stool Culture in selective media
  • Demonstrating Toxin by Hep-2 cell cultures
  • Toxin gene identification by Enzyme immunoassay
  • Colonscopy or sigmoidoscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure strain isolation from culture: Stool culture on selective media can identify C. difficile. However, it is not the best method due to longer turnaround times and the need for specialized techniques. It is highly sensitive but less practical for rapid diagnosis. Also the mere presence of clostridium difficile does not suggest infection with the organism unless toxin production is checked.

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence:

Immunofluorescence can be used for detecting C. difficile antigens. It is less commonly used due to the complexity of the procedure and lower sensitivity compared to PCR.

 

Option D. Toxin Detection by ELISA: ELISA can detect toxins in stool samples. Although it is a useful method, it is less sensitive and specific compared to PCR, making it a secondary choice for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for diagnosing Clostridium difficile infection is through nucleic acid amplification tests, such as PCR assays, which detect the toxin A or B genes in stool due to their high sensitivity, specificity, and rapid turnaround time.

choices.text: A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine
A- Aldosterone, B- Androgen, C- Cortisol, D- Epinephrine
A- Aldosterone, B- Epinephrine, C- Androgen, D- Cortisol
A- Cortisol, B- Aldosterone, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

questions.text: Hormones secreted from A, B, C, D are respectively (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

 

The adrenal gland has distinct zones, each responsible for secreting specific hormones:

 

A. Zona Glomerulosa : Secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which regulates blood pressure and electrolyte balance.

 

B. Zona Fasciculata : Secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which regulates metabolism and immune response.

 

C. Zona Reticularis : Secretes androgens, which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

D. Adrenal Medulla : Secretes catecholamines, mainly epinephrine and norepinephrine, which are involved in the fight-or-flight response.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal gland's zones and their respective hormones are:

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: Aldosterone
  • Zona Fasciculata: Cortisol
  • Zona Reticularis: Androgens
  • Adrenal Medulla: Epinephrine

questions.text: Bilateral pedal edema is least likely to be associated with which of the following?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic venous insufficiency

 

Bilateral pedal edema is often due to systemic conditions that lead to fluid retention or increased pressure in the veins.

 

Chronic venous insufficiency, typically results from conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is more likely to cause unilateral (one-sided) pedal edema due to localized obstruction of venous return. While chronic venous insufficiency can sometimes cause bilateral edema, it is less common compared to the other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic renal failure: Patients with chronic renal failure cannot excrete excess fluid properly, leading to fluid retention and generalized edema, including in both legs.

 

Option C. Congestive heart failure: Heart failure results in increased venous pressure and fluid retention, which typically causes dependent edema, including bilateral pedal edema.

 

Option D. Chronic liver disease: Liver disease can lead to hypoalbuminemia and reduced oncotic pressure, causing generalized and bilateral pedal edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic venous insufficiency is least likely to be associated with bilateral pedal edema compared to chronic renal failure, congestive heart failure, and chronic liver disease.

 

Edema results from imbalances in:

 

  1. Hydrostatic pressure (↑ in heart failure)
  2. Oncotic pressure (↓ in liver/kidney disease)
  3. Lymphatic drainage
  4. Capillary permeability

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The given clinical history and histopathological image are suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis

 

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation.

 

Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells (medlar/copper penny bodies)

 

The following are the various dematiaceous species of fungi

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa
  • Cladophialophora carrionii

 

Treatment: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. Chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole may be efficacious for larger lesions. The application of local heat is also beneficial.

 

MEDLAR/ SCLEROTIC BODIES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It does not typically present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: Pheohyphomycosis is a broad term for infections caused by dematiaceous fungi but lacks the characteristic sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with lymphocutaneous lesions but does not show the sclerotic bodies characteristic of Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: Which agency offers seeds and manure as part of applied nutrition programs in schools? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) UNICEF

 

UNICEF

 

Applied Nutrition Program

 

  • UNICEF promoted the scheme by supplying basic equipment for production and training while FAO and WHO were involved in providing technical advice
  • UNICEF provided seeds, manure and water supply equipment for developing School gardens, to be utilized in school feeding programs

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CARE:  - ‘Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere’ supports following project:

 

  • Integrated Nutrition and Health Project
  • Better Health and Nutrition Project
  • Anaemia Control Project
  • Improving Women's Health Project
  • Improved Health Care for Adolescent Girl's Project
  • Child Survival Project
  • Improving Women's Reproductive Health and Family Spacing Project
  • Konkan Integrate Development Project

 

Option B. UNDP:  The basic objective of the UNDP is to help poorer nations develop their human and natural resources more fully. The UNDP projects cover virtually every economic and social sector - agriculture, industry, education and science, health, social welfare, etc.

 

Option D. WHO:  World Health Organization aims at the attainment of the highest level of health by all people, which helps them to lead a socially and economically productive life.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

UNICEF provides seeds, manure, and water supply equipment as part of its Applied Nutrition Program to develop school gardens, which are used in school feeding programs to improve children's nutrition.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alogliptin.

 

Alogliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, an oral class of drugs used in the treatment of diabetes. DPP-4 inhibitors work by preventing the breakdown of GLP-1, thereby increasing the levels of GLP-1 in the body, which in turn enhances insulin secretion, reduces glucagon secretion, and slows gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voglibose: Voglibose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays the absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines. It does not directly affect the levels of incretin hormones like GLP-1 and GIP, nor does it significantly influence glucagon levels.

 

Option C. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analogue that is used to help control blood sugar levels. It is typically administered by injection and does not significantly increase GLP-1 or GIP levels. It works by slowing gastric emptying and suppressing glucagon secretion, but it does not match the profile described in the question as closely as alogliptin.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist, which would indeed lead to increased GLP-1 levels and decreased glucagon levels. However, liraglutide is administered by injection and not orally. This makes it less likely to be the medication described in the scenario, which specifies an oral drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alogliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, is the most likely drug responsible for the increase in GLP-1 and GIP levels and the decrease in glucagon levels in this patient. It effectively lowers HbA1c levels and is administered orally, fitting the description provided.

questions.text: Which of the following given cancers rarely metastasize to the liver? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prostate

 

Prostate Cancers rarely metastasize to the liver.

 

Prostate cancer tends to metastasize to bones via periprostatic venous plexus (Bateson) rather than the liver. Bone metastases are a hallmark of advanced prostate cancer. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colon: Colon cancer commonly metastasizes to the liver. The liver is one of the most common sites of metastasis for colon cancer, and it frequently spreads to the liver through the bloodstream.

 

Option B. Breast: Breast cancer can metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases in breast cancer are not uncommon, and the liver is considered a potential site of spread for breast cancer cells.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma is known for its propensity to metastasize to various organs, including the liver. Liver metastases are common in advanced melanoma cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common malignant tumors of the liver are metastasis. The liver is a common site of metastases from gastrointestinal tumors because of dissemination via the portal venous system. The most relevant such metastatic tumor of the liver to the surgeon is colorectal cancer because of the well-documented potential for long-term survival after its complete resection.

 

The more frequent primary sites include carcinomas of the colon, pancreas, lung, and breast in adults, and neuroblastoma, Wilms tumor, and rhabdomyosarcoma in pediatric patients. Although the origin of the tumor is often known when metastases are biopsied, carcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, and lung are particularly notorious for being occult primary neoplasms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a history of blunt trauma to his right eye sustained during a sports injury one week ago. He complains of blurred vision and photophobia but denies any pain. On slit-lamp examination, the clinician observes a faint circular opacity on the anterior surface of the lens, as shown in the image below. What is the finding marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Vossius ring

 

Explanation:

 

The marked finding in the image is a Vossius ring, which appears as a circular ring of pigmentation on the anterior surface of the lens. This ring is composed of brown amorphous pigment granules that imprint from the iris onto the lens capsule, typically following blunt trauma to the eye.

 

Vossius Ring:

 

A Vossius ring is caused by the forceful backward displacement of the cornea and iris during blunt trauma, which results in the iris imprinting onto the lens surface.

 

It usually has the same diameter as the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

 

Over time, the pigment can resorb, leaving behind discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

A Vossius ring serves as an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye. It does not usually impair vision significantly but indicates the need for further evaluation of ocular damage that may have resulted from the injury.

 

Management:

 

The Vossius ring itself often requires no specific treatment, but the underlying trauma necessitates a thorough ocular examination to assess for other potential injuries, such as hyphema, retinal detachment, or angle recession.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior subcapsular cataract: Opacities that form under the anterior lens capsule, typically associated with aging, trauma, or other ocular conditions, but they do not appear as a ring pattern.

 

Option C. Posterior synechiae: Adhesions between the iris and the lens, often seen in inflammatory conditions like uveitis, not related to blunt trauma in the pattern shown.

 

Option D. Corneal abrasion: Superficial damage to the corneal epithelium, seen as staining defects under fluorescein dye, not involving the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Vossius ring is an imprint of the iris on the anterior lens surface, usually following blunt trauma to the eye. It serves as a key diagnostic clue of prior ocular injury and requires further evaluation to rule out additional trauma-related complications.

choices.text: Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS
Start Antihypertensives and ARM

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks presents with painful bleeding PV, reduced fetal movement, increased uterine tone, and absent FHR. BP is 166/98 mmHg, and the cervix is 6cm dilated, 70% effaced with intact membranes. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Start Antihypertensives and ARM

 

Explanation:

 

Given the high BP and symptoms suggesting placental issues, starting antihypertensives addresses the hypertension, and artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is indicated to advance labor, especially in a context where continuing pregnancy may pose risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Emergency LSCS: An emergency LSCS without addressing hypertension could be risky.

 

Option B. Start Antihypertensives and emergency LSCS: While emergency surgery is critical, managing BP first is essential.

 

Option D. Tocolysis: Tocolysis is contraindicated in hypertensive disorders and fetal distress.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of hypertensive crisis with placental issues, managing maternal BP is crucial before procedures like ARM to safely advance labor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with a history of bipolar disorder has recently been started on lithium therapy. During a follow-up visit, the healthcare provider wants to educate the patient on the signs of lithium toxicity. Which of the following side effects should the patient be instructed to monitor and report immediately as they may indicate lithium toxicity? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ataxia and Diarrhea

 

Ataxia, tinnitus and diarrhea are common signs of lithium toxicity. Lithium has a narrow therapeutic range, meaning that the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Therefore, monitoring for signs of toxicity is crucial. Other signs of lithium toxicity can include tremors, confusion, and vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaise and sore throat: While these symptoms can be concerning, they are not typically associated with lithium toxicity. They might be indicative of an infection or other unrelated conditions.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is not a common sign of lithium toxicity. It may indicate an infection or other illness.

 

Option D. Breathlessness: This symptom is not typically associated with lithium toxicity. Breathlessness might be related to other medical conditions such as respiratory or cardiac issues.

 

Therefore, patients on lithium therapy should be particularly vigilant for symptoms like ataxia and diarrhea, as they could indicate the onset of lithium toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients on lithium therapy should be educated to monitor and immediately report signs of lithium toxicity, such as ataxia and diarrhea, to prevent serious adverse effects.

 

Mnemonic

 

If DAT symptom is present, report to hospital:

 

  • Diarrhea
  • Ataxia
  • Tinnitus

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, plays a crucial role in regulating water balance in the body by concentrating urine. It acts primarily through the aquaporin-2 (AQP-2) channels located in the kidney's collecting ducts. Here is how ADH functions:

 

  1. Receptor Interaction: ADH binds to V2 receptors on the basolateral membranes of cells in the late distal convoluted tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts of the kidney.
  2. Signal Transduction: The binding of ADH to these receptors activates the cyclic AMP (cAMP) pathway, leading to the activation of protein kinase A (PKA).
  3. Aquaporin-2 Mobilization: PKA then phosphorylates specific proteins that lead to the translocation of AQP-2 water channels from intracellular storage vesicles to the apical membrane of the kidney cells.
  4. Water Reabsorption: Once inserted into the membrane, AQP-2 channels allow water to be reabsorbed from the tubular fluid back into the bloodstream, thereby concentrating the urine.
  5. Regulation by ADH Levels: Chronic high levels of ADH enhance the synthesis of AQP-2 channels through increased gene transcription, while low levels lead to the internalization of these channels, reducing water reabsorption.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

In conditions such as nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, there is a genetic mutation that affects the V2 receptors or the AQP-2 channels themselves, rendering the kidney tubules unresponsive to ADH. This results in the inability to concentrate urine and excessive urine output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aquaporin 1: Incorrect, as AQP-1 is primarily involved in passive water transport in other parts of the kidney and other tissues, not under the control of ADH.

 

Option C. Aquaporin 3 and Option D. Aquaporin 4: Both are incorrect as these aquaporins are located in the basolateral membrane of collecting duct cells and are involved in water transport but are not the primary channels through which ADH acts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADH specifically regulates the body's water balance by acting through aquaporin-2 channels in the kidney's collecting ducts, facilitating the reabsorption of water back into the bloodstream and thus concentrating the urine. This mechanism is crucial for maintaining proper hydration and electrolyte balance in the body.

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

 

  • The image shows hesitation cuts.
  • It is a series of shallow cuts made by people considering a suicide attempt.
  • These wounds are often multiple, parallel, non-lethal cuts.
  • The throat, and wrist are the most common sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grazed abrasion: Grazed abrasions occur when the skin is rubbed or scraped against a rough surface, leading to the removal of the superficial layers of the skin. This does not match the image shown, which depicts clean, linear cuts.

 

Option C. Laceration: Lacerations are deeper tears or cuts in the skin caused by blunt trauma. They are typically irregular and have abraded edges. The image shows clean, linear cuts, not consistent with lacerations.

 

Option D. Patterned bruise: Patterned bruises are caused by an object leaving a distinct pattern on the skin, such as from a belt or other implement. The marks in the image are linear and clean, not consistent with the diffuse and patterned nature of bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

questions.text: Which of the following infection presents with mucus in stools and abdominal pain? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba

 

Stools with mucus and abdominal pain are seen in infection due to Entamoeba.

 

Clinical features of intestinal amebiasis:

 

  • Dysentery accompanied by lower abdominal discomfort and flatulence. Stools usually have blood and mucus.
  • Chronic amebiasis presents with low-grade symptoms such as occasional diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue.
  • A granulomatous lesion called an ameboma may form in the cecal or rectosigmoid areas of the colon which can resemble an adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Giardia: Is often asymptomatic, but in some cases can lead to fat malabsorption, dull epigastric pain, and flatulence. BUT does not release mucus in stool.

 

Option C. Campylobacter: Presents with fever, pain and watery diarrhea. Stool contains leucocytes and blood.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcal food poisoning is toxin-mediated and presents with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entamoeba histolytica infection presents with dysentery, characterized by stools containing mucus and blood, along with abdominal pain.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Vulval cancer has several known risk factors, which include:

 

  • Chronic vulval irritation: Persistent irritation and inflammation can contribute to the development of vulval cancer.
  • Immunosuppressive conditions: Conditions such as pregnancy and HIV infection can compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of vulval cancer.
  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with HPV, particularly strains 16 and 18, is a significant risk factor.
  • Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for various cancers, including vulval cancer.
  • Condyloma (anogenital warts): Caused by HPV, these warts can lead to changes in vulval cells that may progress to cancer.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs): History of STDs can increase the risk due to the association with HPV and chronic inflammation.
  • Vulvar dystrophies: Conditions like lichen sclerosus can predispose individuals to vulval cancer.

 

Vulval hamartoma is not a risk factor for vulval cancer. Hamartomas are benign, disorganized clusters of tissue that do not typically transform into malignant tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval dystrophy: Vulval dystrophies, such as lichen sclerosus, are risk factors for vulval cancer due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

 

Option C. Smoking: Smoking is a well-documented risk factor for many cancers, including vulval cancer.

 

Option D. Vulval warts: Vulval warts, often caused by HPV, can lead to cellular changes that increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 680, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 334

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a male patient in his early twenties who presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of abdominal pain and obstipation, and reports blunt injury to the abdomen 3 days prior? The provided X-ray image may provide clues to the diagnosis: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • The given radiograph in the erect position indicates air under the diaphragm, which is a typical finding in cases of hollow viscus perforation.
  • A history of trauma, accompanied by symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, supports the diagnosis of a perforation of the alimentary tract.

 

A perforation of a hollow organ (like the intestines or stomach) can lead to air and contents of the organ leaking into the abdominal cavity. It can be a result of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemothorax: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of blood within the pleural cavity, often due to trauma. The patient's symptoms are abdominal in nature and not respiratory, making this an unlikely diagnosis. Hemothorax would be evident on a chest X-ray.

 

Option C. Pneumothorax: This is the presence of air in the pleural cavity, often due to trauma or a spontaneous event, leading to lung collapse. Similar to hemothorax, this condition is related to the respiratory system and would not be the cause of abdominal pain or obstipation.

 

Option D. Intestinal obstruction: This condition involves a blockage that prevents the contents of the intestines from passing normally through the digestive tract. However, no free air should be seen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hollow viscus perforation can cause acute bacterial peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum that can be localized or generalized.
  • Clinical features of peritonitis include abdominal pain that worsens with movement, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, and guarding on palpation. Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.
  • An erect abdominal radiograph that shows free gas under the diaphragm.
  • Management of peritonitis involves general care of the patient in terms of nutritional support and pain relief. Laparotomy and surgical treatment of the cause is usually necessary.

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Attached to pelvic brim

 

Explanation:

 

The levator ani is not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, it originates from the posterior surface of the body of the pubis, the obturator fascia, and the ischial spine. It then inserts into the coccyx, anococcygeal ligament, and walls of the prostate or vagina, rectum, and anal canal. The incorrect notion about its attachment to the pelvic brim is a common misconception.

 

  • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  •  Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supports pelvic viscera: This statement is correct. The levator ani, along with other pelvic floor muscles, forms a supportive sling for the pelvic organs such as the bladder, uterus (in females), and rectum. This muscular support is essential for maintaining continence and facilitating functions such as micturition and defecation.

 

Option B. Converge downwards and medially: This statement is also correct. The fibers of the levator ani muscles, especially from the pubococcygeus, tend to converge towards the midline and run in a downward direction. This orientation provides the necessary support to the pelvic organs and creates a muscular barrier between the pelvic cavity and the perineum.

 

Option C. Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus: This statement is partially true. The levator ani is made up of three parts: the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus. All three parts contribute to the function and support provided by the levator ani. Thus, while the statement includes two components of the levator ani, it omits the puborectalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic brim is not connected to the levator ani muscle. It originates from the ischial spine, levator ani's arcus tendinous (a thickened section of the obturator fascia, and the pubic body.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) was described by the WHO in 2007 and involves mainly three basic steps:

 

  1. Administering a uterotonic: Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV).
  2. Controlled cord traction: This is done only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
  3. Uterine massage: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who have received uterotonics; instead, postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.

 

Key Points:

 

  • AMTSL prevents atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care. This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed.

 

WHO Guidelines:

 

  • In 2012:
    • Emphasized the main three steps.
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice.
    • Controlled cord traction only with a skilled birth attendant.
    • Delayed cord clamping recommended.
  • In 2018:
    • Additional uterotonics that can be used include:
      • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
      • Misoprostol (400 or 600 mcg PO – to be used where a skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
      • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV except in hypertensive women)
      • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
    • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonics after delivery of placenta: This is a key component of AMTSL to prevent atonic PPH.

 

Option B. Controlled cord traction: This is part of the AMTSL process to help deliver the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine massage: This is included in AMTSL, specifically for assessing uterine tone post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe back pain that has progressively worsened over the past 10 days. He also reports new-onset urinary incontinence and difficulty walking. His medical history includes lumbar disc prolapse diagnosed previously. On examination, there is reduced sensation in the perineal area and weakness in both legs. There is no history of fever or weight loss. Considering his symptoms and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cauda equina syndrome

 

Cauda equina syndrome (CES) is a rare but serious condition resulting from compression of the cauda equina, a bundle of nerve roots at the base of the spinal cord in the lumbosacral spinal canal. CES is considered a medical emergency due to the potential for severe and irreversible neurological damage if not promptly treated.

 

Key Points



Pathophysiology:

 

CES occurs when the nerves in the cauda equina are compressed, interrupting their function and causing severe symptoms. These nerves are responsible for motor and sensory function to the legs and control of the bladder.

 

Causes of Cauda Equina Syndrome:

 

The most common cause is lumbar disc herniation. Other causes include trauma, spinal tumors, spinal stenosis, infection, and vertebral fractures due to osteoporosis.

 

Symptoms:

 

Severe low back pain.

 

Bladder dysfunction such as urinary retention or incontinence.

 

Bowel incontinence.

 

Muscle weakness or sensory loss in both legs.

 

Loss of motor function in the legs and reduction of reflexes.

 

Saddle anesthesia, which refers to the loss of sensation in areas that would be in contact with a saddle (inner thighs, buttocks, and perineal area).

 

Investigations:

 

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): The best imaging modality to assess the spinal cord, nerve roots, and soft tissues, identifying the extent of nerve compression and the underlying cause.

 

Myelogram: Involves injecting dye into the spinal column, followed by X-ray or CT scanning, to visualize pressure on the cauda equina.

 

Treatment:

 

CES often requires emergency decompression surgery to relieve pressure on the nerve roots. Early surgery offers the best chance of improving motor and sensory function and restoring bladder and bowel control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cauda equina syndrome is a severe condition resulting from nerve compression in the lumbosacral spinal canal, commonly due to lumbar disc herniation. Recognizing the symptoms, such as severe back pain, urinary incontinence, and saddle anesthesia, is critical, as prompt surgical intervention is essential to prevent permanent neurological damage

questions.text: A Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear is prepared. Which of the following cannot be diagnosed? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxiella burnetii

 

Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. The diagnosis of Coxiella burnetii is typically made through serology for specific antibodies rather than Giemsa staining.

 

Giemsa stain is a differential stain which is made up of a combination of reagents (Azure, Methylene blue, and Eosin dye) used widely in cytogenetics and histopathology for the diagnosis of:

 

  • Malaria, spirochetes and other blood parasites
  • Chlamydia trachomatis inclusion bodies
  • Borrelia spp
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Histoplasma spp
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci cysts
  • Bartonella henselae
  • Ehrlichia chaffeensis
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Talaromyces marneffei (formerly called Penicillium marneffei)

 

In parasitology to detect intraerythrocytic (plasmodia, babesiae) and exoerythrocytic (trypanosomes, microfilaria) parasites. It is also used for the detection of intracellular amastigotes of Leishmania species or Trypanosoma cruzi. Giemsa stain is also used for the laboratory diagnosis of Toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toxoplasma gondii: Giemsa stain is used for the laboratory diagnosis of toxoplasmosis, which involves the detection of intracellular organisms.

 

Option C. Bartonella henselae: Giemsa stain can be used to identify Bartonella henselae, particularly in blood smears.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: Giemsa stain is effective in diagnosing infections caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis by identifying the morulae within white blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:
