Coxiella burnetii cannot be diagnosed using a Giemsa stain of a thin peripheral smear. Serology for specific antibodies is the method used for its diagnosis. Giemsa stain is a versatile stain used to diagnose a variety of blood parasites and intracellular pathogen.

choices.text: Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiate delirium from dementia in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acuity of onset and loss of consciousness

 

Delirium is characterized by an acute and fluctuating onset with disturbances in consciousness and attention. Dementia, such as Alzheimer's disease, has a gradual, insidious onset and is primarily a disorder of memory without loss of consciousness.

 

Delirium and dementia, though distinct syndromes, can sometimes overlap in presentation, making differentiation challenging. However, some key features can help differentiate the two:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acuity of onset and agitation: While the acuity of onset can differentiate the two, both delirium and dementia can be associated with agitation.

 

Option C. Visual hallucinations and impaired memory: Visual hallucinations are more common in delirium and some types of dementia like Lewy Body Dementia but not necessarily Alzheimer's disease. Impaired memory is a feature of dementia, primarily Alzheimer's, but can also be present in delirium.

 

Option D. Agitation and irritation: Both can be seen in either delirium or dementia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 22.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Water’s view

 

Occipitomental view is also called Water's view.

 

Water's view: The patient's head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward.

 

Structures seen in Water's view are:

 

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Infratemporal fossa

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's view - Typically used for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital bone and foramen magnum.

 

 

Structures seen – 

Arcuate eminence

Superior semicircular canal

Mastoid antrum

Internal auditory canal

Tympanic cavity

Cochlea

External auditory canal

 

Clinical application – Acoustic neuroma, Petrositis

 

Option C. Law's view - Generally related to imaging of the shoulder or elbow, not applicable here.

 

Option D. Stenver's view - A radiographic projection used primarily for detailed imaging of the mastoid process and middle ear structures.

Structures seen –

Arcuate eminence

Internal auditory meatus

Labyrinth with vestibule

Mastoid antrum

Cochlea

Entire petrous pyramid

 

 

Educational Objective:


Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: Identify the following instrument commonly used in obstetrics? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Episiotomy scissors

 

The instrument shown in the picture is an episiotomy scissors. The angulation in the scissor is designed to prevent the extension of a pelvic tear into the anal margins and to avoid obstetric anal sphincter injuries or complete perineal tears.

 

An episiotomy is not given routinely. Its use should be restricted to specific situations such as:

 

  • Macrosomia: When the baby is larger than average.
  • After coming head of breech: To facilitate the delivery of the head in a breech birth.
  • Instrumental delivery: When tools like forceps or vacuum are used to assist in delivery.
  • Shoulder dystocia: A delivery complication where the baby's shoulders get stuck.
  • Rigid perineum: Often seen in primigravida, where the perineum does not stretch easily.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mayo scissors: General-purpose surgical scissors used for cutting tissues.

 

Option B. Curved scissors: Scissors with a curved blade, used for various surgical procedures but not specifically for episiotomy.

 

Option C. Suture remover: Scissors designed specifically for removing sutures, not for performing an episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum to facilitate childbirth and prevent severe perineal tears. Their use is restricted to specific obstetric situations to avoid unnecessary complications.

 

Ref: Page no 755 Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Thirst

 

Thirst is recognized as the most reliable feature of some dehydration. When dehydration begins to set in, the body's initial response is to signal thirst as a way to encourage fluid intake. This response is consistent across various cases of mild to moderate dehydration. Unlike other symptoms, thirst is a direct and early indicator of dehydration that can be easily recognized by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: Skin turgor, or the delayed return of the skin to its normal position after being pinched, is influenced by several factors, including nutritional status. This makes it less reliable as a sole indicator of dehydration.

 

Option B. Lethargy: Lethargy can be a symptom of dehydration, but it is difficult to quantify and may vary widely depending on the individual's overall health and the severity of dehydration.

 

Option D. Sunken eyes: The appearance of sunken eyes is quite subjective and often requires the input of a caregiver, such as a parent, to determine whether it is present. It is also not always a definitive sign of dehydration, making it less reliable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ptosis of right eye

 

The patient has ptosis of the right eye. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. Ptosis is generally unilateral, in over 70% of individuals. The drooping in this case is significant enough to cover a portion of the pupil, thereby obstructing part of the visual field, which is characteristic of ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entropion of right eye: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid margin, not observed in the provided image.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos of right eye: Refers to the inability to close the eyelids completely, not evident here.

 

Option D. Exophthalmos of left eye: Characterized by the protrusion of the eyeball, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis, particularly of the type seen in this patient, is typically caused by a dysfunction or disconnection of the levator muscle or its aponeurosis, either congenital or acquired.

 

Types:

 

 

Note: Pseudoptosis is apparent but not true drooping of the eyelid. Causes include lack of support of the lids by the globe (orbital volume deficit like an artificial eye, microphthalmos, or enophthalmos), contralateral lid retraction, ipsilateral hypotropia, brow ptosis, or dermatochalasis.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linea semilunaris

 

Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

 

The linea semilunaris is a curved tendinous line located on either side of the rectus abdominis muscle, representing the lateral border where the flat abdominal muscles' aponeuroses come together.

 

It is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique alone. Instead, it is formed where the aponeurosis of the external oblique, the internal oblique, and the transversus abdominis meet and fuse before they envelop the rectus abdominis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal Ligament: Also known as Cooper's ligament, the pectineal ligament is a fibrous band that runs parallel and posterior to the inguinal ligament, extending from the pubic tubercle to the pectineal line of the pubis. While it is closely related to structures formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, it is not directly derived from it.

 

Option B. Inguinal Ligament: The inguinal ligament is directly derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle. It is the inferior edge of the external oblique aponeurosis, stretching between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle. This ligament acts as a boundary between the anterior abdominal wall and the thigh, and structures like the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament in females pass beneath it to enter the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. Lacunar Ligament: Also called Gimbernat’s ligament, the lacunar ligament is a crescent-shaped fold of the aponeurosis of the external oblique that attaches to the pectineal line of the pubis. It's positioned medial to the inguinal ligament, and its formation is related to the deepening of the inguinal canal during development. It contributes to the posterior margin of the superficial inguinal ring and represents the lateral border of the femoral canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments derived from external oblique aponeurosis are:

questions.text: An HIV patient came to the clinic with a history of diarrhea. Stool microscopy showed the oocysts that were 4-8 µm in size. The image is shown below. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptosporidium

 

The given clinical scenario and the stool microscopy show oocysts of Cryptosporidium.

 

Cryptosporidium is a coccidian parasite. The two cryptosporidium species responsible for traveller’s diarrhoea are C. hominis and C. parvum.

 

 

Sporulated oocysts, containing 4 sporozoites, are excreted by the infected host through feces image (and possibly other routes such as respiratory secretions).

 

Transmission of Cryptosporidium spp. occurs mainly through ingestion of fecally contaminated water (e.g., drinking or recreational water) or food (e.g., raw milk) or following direct contact with infected animals or people.

 

Following ingestion (and possibly inhalation) by a suitable host image, excystation occurs. The sporozoites are released and parasitize the epithelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract (and possibly the respiratory tract).

 

In these cells, usually within the brush border, the parasites undergo asexual multiplication (schizogony or merogony) and then sexual multiplication (gametogony) producing microgamonts (male) image and macrogamonts (female).

 

Upon fertilization of the macrogamonts by the microgametes that rupture from the macrogamont, oocysts develop and sporulate in the infected host.

 

Zygotes give rise to two different types of oocysts (thick-walled and thin-walled. Thick-walled oocysts are excreted from the host into the environment, whereas thin-walled oocysts are involved in the internal autoinfective cycle and are not recovered from stools.

 

Oocysts are infectious upon excretion, thus enabling direct and immediate fecal-oral transmission.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Isospora (now Cystoisospora): Isospora belli oocysts are larger, measuring about 20-30 µm by 10-19 µm. They typically contain two sporocysts, each with four sporozoites. Isosporiasis is less common than cryptosporidiosis and presents with gastrointestinal symptoms in immunocompromised individuals. Isospora oocysts are acid-fast but larger than Cryptosporidium.

 

Option B. Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts are also coccidian parasites but are slightly larger, measuring about 8-10 µm in diameter. Cyclospora infections can cause prolonged diarrhea but are distinguished by their size and autofluorescence under ultraviolet light, which is different from Cryptosporidium.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites that also cause diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients. However, their spores are much smaller (1-2 µm) and they do not exhibit the same morphological characteristics as Cryptosporidium oocysts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptosporidium oocysts are small (4-8 µm) coccidian parasites responsible for causing diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. They are identified in stool samples by their size and acid-fast staining properties.

questions.text: The most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis is? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Morphology

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperm is considered the most important marker of male fertility. While sperm concentration and progressive motility are valuable for distinguishing between fertile and infertile men, strict sperm morphology is the most discriminating factor in assessing male fertility potential.

 

Morphological abnormalities in spermatozoa can be identified in various parts, including the head, neck, mid-piece, and tail. These abnormalities can result from defective spermatogenesis or certain epididymal pathologies, leading to increased morphological defects in the sperm. Spermatozoa with abnormal morphology have a lower fertilizing potential, making morphology a critical parameter in semen analysis for determining fertility.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Concentration: Sperm concentration is an important parameter, but it is not as critical as morphology in predicting fertility. The WHO 2021 standard for sperm concentration is 16 million/ml.

 

Option C. Motility: Progressive motility is significant, with the WHO 2021 standard being 30%, but it is not the most crucial parameter compared to morphology.

 

Option D. Sperm Count: While total sperm count is important, it is encompassed under concentration and motility measures. Morphology remains the most critical individual parameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most important marker of male fertility in semen analysis, as it directly correlates with the fertilizing potential of the sperm.

 

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg443, https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789240030787

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male presents to your clinic after a dog bite earlier in the day. Physical examination reveals a 1.5 cm abrasion with some oozing. Given the nature of the wound and the potential interventions post-exposure, which combination of actions and descriptors best characterizes the appropriate management? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Category 3 wound
  2. Wash the wound with normal tap water for 15-20 minutes
  3. Clean the wound with spirit
  4. Loose suturing of the wound with a proper dressing
  5. Equine immunoglobin is given at a dose of 40 IU/kg of body weight, twice
  6. Intra-dermal vaccine is administered on days 0, 3, 7, 28
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 2, 3, 6

 

The patient with a dog bite presented with an abrasion, which comes under category 3 wound.

 

The components of post–exposure prophylaxis are:

 

  1. Local treatment of wound
  2. Antibiotics and anti-tetanus measures
  3. Active immunization against rabies – if indicated
  4. Passive immunization with rabies immunoglobulin – if indicated
  5. Observe the animal for 10 days from the day of bite:
    • If healthy after 10 days: Discontinue post – exposure vaccination
    • If dies within observation period: complete PEP
    • If observation not possible: complete the post – exposure vaccination

 

Other Option: 

 

Statement 4 – Abrasion wound doesn’t require suturing

 

Statement 5 – Equine Rabies Ig at dose of 40 IU/kg should be given only once.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C2A

 

  • Given the scenario showing asymptomatic varicose veins, it corresponds to C2a in the CEAP classification system.
  • C2A: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are asymptomatic (suffix A).
  • The CEAP classification system is used to categorize varicose veins based on their clinical characteristics.
  • The acronym stands for Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2S: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are symptomatic (suffix S), meaning the patient would experience symptoms like pain, aching, swelling, or other discomforts. Since the patient reports no discomfort, this is not the correct classification.

 

Option C. C4a: This stage represents more advanced skin changes, such as pigmentation or eczema, due to chronic venous disease. The patient only has varicose veins without skin changes, so this classification is incorrect.

 

Option D. C1: Represents telangiectasia or reticular veins, which are smaller than varicose veins. The image and clinical description indicate larger varicose veins, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.
  •  For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.

choices.text: Measure from the tip of the nose to the mid-sternum.
Measure from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule, then down to the xiphisternum.
Insert the tube until resistance is met, then pull back slightly.
Measure from the mouth to the belly button.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, suspected to be due to an intestinal obstruction. The clinical team decides to insert a nasogastric (NG) tube for gastric decompression. The nurse asks about the correct technique to measure the appropriate length of the NG tube for proper placement. What is the most appropriate method to measure the placement of the nasogastric tube?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Measure from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule, then down to the xiphisternum.

 

The most appropriate technique to measure the length of a nasogastric tube is the N-E-X method, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose (N), past the ear lobule (E), and down to the xiphisternum (X). This method ensures the tube is correctly positioned within the stomach, without being too long or too short, thereby minimizing complications.

 

Key Points:

 

N-E-X Measurement Technique:

 

The N-E-X method is commonly used to determine the correct length of a nasogastric tube for insertion, ensuring it reaches the stomach effectively. This method prevents the tube from being placed incorrectly, which could lead to complications such as feeding into the respiratory tract.

 

Confirmation of Proper Placement:

 

After insertion, proper tube placement should be confirmed by auscultating the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by using an abdominal radiograph. Correct positioning ensures that the NG tube is within the stomach, particularly important when used for suction or feeding.

 

Indications and Contraindications:

 

NG tubes are indicated for gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric contents, nutritional support, and medication administration. Absolute contraindications include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

Insertion Procedure:

 

The preferred patient position is sitting with the neck slightly flexed to facilitate the insertion process.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure from the tip of the nose to the mid-sternum: This method does not provide an accurate measure of the distance needed for the tube to reach the stomach and could result in improper tube placement.

 

Option C. Insert the tube until resistance is met, then pull back slightly: This approach is unsafe and unreliable as it does not ensure proper placement within the stomach and could lead to complications, such as entering the respiratory tract.

 

Option D. Measure from the mouth to the belly button: This method is incorrect and does not provide a standardized way to ensure the tube reaches the stomach appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The N-E-X method is the standard technique for measuring the length of a nasogastric tube, ensuring it reaches the stomach without complications. Proper measurement, placement confirmation, and patient positioning are essential to safely and effectively manage NG tube use.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE

 

The given clinical features suggest a anaphylactic reaction, a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by immunoglobulin E.

 

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies.

 

It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

 

Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (such as the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g. peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g. those in bee venom).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is mainly involved in mucosal immunity and does not play a primary role in type I hypersensitivity or anaphylactic reactions.

 

Option C. IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response but is not involved in allergic or type I hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is involved in various immune responses, including type II and type III hypersensitivity reactions, but not in the immediate hypersensitivity reaction that leads to anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgE is the immunoglobulin responsible for mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as anaphylaxis, which can occur in response to bee stings or other allergens.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 373

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness of the right side of the face with the loss of pain and temperature. Pain and temperature sensation of the left leg is also lost. The lesion is most likely located at?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lateral pons

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome which occurs due to a lesion located at lateral pons

 

 

Lateral Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The facial nerve or its nucleus leading to ipsilateral facial weakness. (differentiating feature from lateral medullary syndrome).
  • The spinothalamic tract leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial Medulla: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract leading to contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The medial lemniscus leading to contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • The hypoglossal nerve leading to ipsilateral tongue deviation.
  • This doesn't match the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Medial Pons: Lesions here would affect:

 

  • The corticospinal tract causing contralateral hemiparesis.
  • The abducens nerve leading to ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle palsy.
  • The medial lemniscus causing contralateral loss of tactile and proprioceptive sensations.
  • This doesn't align with the symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lateral Medulla: Lesions in this region (often due to Wallenberg syndrome or lateral medullary syndrome) would result in:

 

  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the face due to the involvement of the descending tract and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body due to the involvement of the spinothalamic tract.
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, and decreased gag reflex due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus.
  • Vertigo, nausea, nystagmus due to vestibular nuclei involvement.
  • Ataxia and dysmetria because of the involvement of the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
  • While some symptoms match, the facial weakness characteristic of facial nerve involvement is not a feature of lateral medullary lesions.
  • If there was no mention of facial weakness then lateral medullary syndrome would had been the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

 

Stroke symptoms

 

Rule of 4’s

 

  1. 4 cranial nerves originate above pons (2 in midbrain), 4 in pons, 4 in medulla
  2. 4 midline cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12) (divide equally into 12 except 1 and 2)
  3. 4 Midline structures that begin with M 
    • Motor pathway (aka corticospinal tract)
    • Medial lemniscus
    • Medial longitudinal fasciculus
    • Medial cranial nerves (CN 3, 4, 6, 12)
  4. 4 structures to the Side that begin with S 
    • Spinocerebellar pathway (ipsilateral ataxia of arm and leg)
    • Spinothalamic pathway
    • Sensory portion of CN V
    • Sympathetic pathway

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia

 

The false statement regarding acitretin is that it is contra-indicated in persons with hyperlipidemia.

 

Although, acitretin can result in increase in serum LDL-cholesterol and triglycerides and decrease in HDL-cholesterol, this adverse effect is more likely in patients with disturbances of lipid metabolism, diabetes mellitus, obesity, increased alcohol intake, or a familial history of these conditions. Therefore, serum lipids must be more closely monitored in high-risk patients and during long-term treatment. Dietary modifications, reduction in dose, or drug therapy should be employed to control significant elevations of triglycerides. If, despite these measures, hypertriglyceridemia and low HDL levels persist, the discontinuation of acitretin should be considered. So, acitretin is not contra-indicated in these patients, but should be used cautiously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acitretin can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight, and patients should be advised to use sun protection and avoid excessive sun exposure during therapy.

 

Option C. Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 3 years after therapy: Female patients of childbearing age should avoid getting pregnant after therapy because acitretin is teratogenic and can cause fetal malformations. Effective contraception should be used during treatment and for at least 3 years after therapy.

 

Option D. Acitretin has a half-life of about 50 hours, which means it can take several weeks for the drug to be eliminated from the body after discontinuing therapy. This long half-life also means that accumulation of the drug can occur with repeated dosing, increasing the risk of toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acitretin is not contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia, although lipid levels should be monitored during therapy. The drug increases sensitivity to sunlight, requires women to avoid pregnancy for 3 years after therapy due to its teratogenicity, and has a long half-life of about 50 hours.

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding disulfiram?

 

1. Stops alcohol craving

 

2. Accumulates acetaldehyde

 

3. Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase

 

4. Starting dose is 500 mg
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  1 and 3

 

  • Alcohol is metabolized in the body with the help of alcohol dehydrogenase to aldehyde and further to acid with the help of aldehyde dehydrogenase.
  • Disulfiram inhibits Acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, which leads to accumulation of aldehyde in the body. This causes unpleasant symptoms like headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, etc. after consumption of alcohol due to the accumulated acetaldehyde.
  • So, disulfiram is used in alcohol aversion therapy, however it does not stop craving.
  • It should not be administered until the person has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours.
  • The disulfiram-alcohol reaction may persist as long as 14 days after the last dose of disulfiram.
  • Starting dose of disulfiram is 250 mg is also wrong as starting dose is 500mg/day for 1 week followed by 250 mg /day.

 

Other Options:

 

2.  Accumulates acetaldehyde: True. Disulfiram works by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase, an enzyme involved in metabolizing alcohol. This inhibition leads to the accumulation of acetaldehyde when alcohol is consumed, causing the unpleasant effects.

 

4.  Starting dose is 500 mg: True. Starting dose of disulfiram is 250 mg is also wrong as starting dose is 500 mg/day for 1 week followed by 250 mg/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Disulfiram does not reduce alcohol cravings; it works by causing adverse reactions when alcohol is consumed, thereby discouraging drinking. It inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, not alcohol dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde and subsequent unpleasant symptoms. The starting dose for disulfiram therapy is typically 250 mg per day.

questions.text: Thrombosis is initiated by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelial injury

 

Thrombosis is initiated by endothelial injury.

 

Thrombosis is the formation of a blood clot inside a blood vessel, obstructing the flow of blood through the circulatory system.

 


 

Three primary abnormalities, known as the Virchow triad, are known to cause thrombosis.

 

They include:

 

  • Endothelial injury - most important factor
  • Stasis or turbulent blood flow
  • Hypercoagulability of the blood

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet activation: While platelet activation is a crucial step in the formation of a thrombus, it is typically initiated by endothelial injury, making endothelial injury the primary initiating event.

 

Option C. Coagulation cascade: The coagulation cascade is activated following endothelial injury and platelet activation, but it is not the initiating event of thrombosis.

 

Option D. Vasoconstriction of vessels: Vasoconstriction occurs as a response to endothelial injury and helps limit blood flow to the site of injury, but it is not the initiating factor in thrombosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombosis is primarily initiated by endothelial injury, which is a key component of the Virchow triad and leads to the subsequent activation of platelets and the coagulation cascade.
